about: Dr. R G Brajesh is an Assistant Professor in the Department of Biomedical Engineering and Bioinformatics at Chhattisgarh Swami Vivekanand Technical University, Bhilai (C.G.), India.

His areas of interest include systems biology, evolutionary biology, machine learning in healthcare, and machine learning in agricultural science. His research focuses on understanding complex biological systems through computational modeling and machine learning approaches, with applications in both healthcare and agricultural domains.

research.summary: My research focuses on systems biology, evolutionary biology, and the application of machine learning techniques to biological and agricultural problems. Current projects include AI-based crop health monitoring using drone imagery, computational modeling of genetic regulatory networks, and understanding evolutionary adaptation in microbial systems. I am particularly interested in developing interpretable machine learning models that can provide biological insights and practical solutions for healthcare and agricultural challenges.

ongoingProjects.title: AI-Based Crop Health Monitoring with High-Resolution Drone Images
ongoingProjects.description: Developing an AI-powered system for monitoring crop health using high-resolution drone imagery. The project focuses on early detection of plant diseases and nutrient deficiencies through computer vision and machine learning techniques, enabling precision agriculture practices for improved crop yields.

ongoingProjects.title: Computational Modeling of Genetic Regulatory Networks
ongoingProjects.description: Investigating the dynamics of genetic regulatory networks using mathematical and computational modeling approaches. This research aims to understand how gene expression is controlled and how mutations affect cellular phenotypes, with implications for evolutionary biology and synthetic biology applications.

ongoingProjects.title: Machine Learning for Disease Diagnosis in Resource-Limited Settings
ongoingProjects.description: Developing lightweight machine learning models for automated disease diagnosis that can operate effectively in resource-constrained clinical settings. The project focuses on creating interpretable AI tools that assist healthcare workers in rural areas with limited access to specialized medical expertise.
